page.title: 01Geology-Llanhari area
page.content: The area surveyed by our school lies north and east of the village of Llanhari in Mid-Glam.Most of the area is undulating land between 50 and 100m above sea level.The lowest lying land is found in the east of the area in the valley of the river Ely, whilst to the north the land rises steeply to 120m on Mynydd Garthmaelwg (269m),part of a south facing scarp formed by the Pennant measures. In the south the area is underlain by Carboniferous limestone which gives way northwards to Millstone grit and the coal and shales of the Lower coal series.North of Llanhari village the Carboniferous limestone is overlain by Triassic marls and much of the surface of the area elsewhere is covered by more recent deposits of boulder clay or alluvium,giving rise to a wide range of soil conditions.
